Thanks in advance,
G3, 6740.

I’m going to hazard a guess they mean 2 runs of some sort of rope or cable on a single spool.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-01-22T18:21:16.286Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424337,"topic_slug":"pulling-2-wires-with-1-pulley","display_username":"Nathan Shepherd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M"},"post_url":"/t/pulling-2-wires-with-1-pulley/424337/3","custom_user_title":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3131920,"name":"Andrew H.","username":"ash4fun","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ash4fun/{size}/65155_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-22T18:57:02.592Z","cooked":"

Depending on what you’re trying to do, you can

  • use two seperate pulleys (or perhaps a double-grooved pulley), and run two seperate lines from your end attachments to two connected spools (or one long one), or
  • tie a rope to both end attachment points, leaving plenty of slack. Then tie a line over the pulley between the connecting rope and the spool.

Additionally, I would reccomend considering whether your design actually requires two end attachments. For example, most elevators work just fine with one line with an attachment point and pulley reasonably close to the center.

I would not recommend trying to run two ropes through one pulley or trying to coil two ropes on one spool without some sort of divider.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-01-22T18:57:02.592Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":126.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424337,"topic_slug":"pulling-2-wires-with-1-pulley","display_username":"Andrew H.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31984,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast"},"post_url":"/t/pulling-2-wires-with-1-pulley/424337/4","custom_user_title":"Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3131922,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-22T19:03:11.549Z","cooked":"

Yeah, “pulling” in the title tends to lend itself a bit more to a spool than to a pulley. There was a good thread 226 (hammerheads) started on a similar topic this season, albeit about attaching lager diameter spools to shafts. I’ll see if I can find that.

How to Create an Elevator Spindle >1.25" OD Technical Discussion
In the past we have used the metal Versatube as an elevator spindle for the cord to wrap around. We want to use a hollow spindle with a 2.5"-3" OD but we are unable to find a sustainable solution. We don’t want to use 3D printed parts. We are limited to using a CNC, mill, and lathe. Any recommendations? Here is an example from 4587 in 2018: [image] Edit: The main issue is finding a way to securely put a hub inside a polycarb tube. We are opposed to press fitting. We want to bolt a versahub …

–

ash4fun:

Additionally, I would reccomend considering whether your design actually requires two end attachments. For example, most elevators work just fine with one line with an attachment point and pulley reasonably close to the center.

There is a big difference between “work just fine” and “are robust”

IMO, all else equal, the small weight penalty from running two ropes is far less than the penalty that occurs when something goes wrong due to one set of rigging. There may be other considerations such as packaging that dictate divination from a pair of ropes, but still.

Also with regard to “wire” in the title. Wire rope (“cable”, or broadly speaking what is used on a suspension bridge (although wire rope is a whole other field of engineering in of itself)) is not commonly used in FRC. Dyneema rope has very similar strength characteristics, better radius of curvature, won’t stab you and is a heck of a lot easier to work with (make sure to look up appropriate knots). It does elongate a bit as it relaxes (so you will probably want a turnbuckle in the system), but it does not stretch much at all (less need for a spring in the system).

Samson Rope

AMSTEEL-BLUE - Samson Rope

Sometimes called the world's strongest rope, AmSteel®-Blue by Samson Rope is a torque-free 12-strand braid that, size-for-size, is as strong as steel but outlasts wire 3:1, making it an excellent wire rope replacement. Now available in bio-based...

10 feet of Rope 1/8 in. diameter

This is the Rope used in the AndyMark Climber in a Box. With a tensile strength of 2,500 lbs and a 1/8 in. thickness, this rope is perfect for an FRC elevator or winch system (or whatever else you find it to be useful for. It's a strong rope. You can...
